ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Technical art analysis skills, close looking skills (to a stronger degree than other typical HSAR courses), a bit of chemistry knowledge, and how museums manage conservation

Technical skills should be considered a requirement for all HSAR majors given the level of knowledge I earned in this class. Regardless if students aim to become curators, researchers, or professors, a working knowledge of conservation seems necessary for the good of object preservation.
Learned about conservation techniques and technologies and how to apply that knowledge to artworks.

Really fantastic course that introduced me to the field of art conservation. The course covered a wide range of topics, from the construction of panel paintings, history of pigments, to analytical techniques used by conservators and conservation scientists.
I learned about methods of understanding art using imaging and other techniques.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I appreciated how hands-on the course was. Anne and Irma brought in new artworks every week that related to the lecture's topic that day. This hands-on component and close engagement with the artworks allowed me to solidify my understanding of course material and additionally strengthen my skills in close looking and visual analysis.

This course could potentially have had a more linear flow of ideas. Though each class contributed to creating a related body of knowledge, it could have been possible to connect every weeks ideas more closely.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to anybody with an interest in art and or conservation. Honestly, I would suggest making a class like this mandatory for HSAR majors. It truly changed my perspective on art, artists, and museums, and I am so thankful that I was able to take it
Absolutely, any student interested in the museum world should take this course.

Yes! Fantastic course, especially for those who are interested in art conservation. Also a very good course for art history majors; technical art history is not taught as much in other courses, so this was a great introduction to the topic!

AMAZING course. Please take this is if you are an art history major, you will not regret it! Anne and Irma are both wonderful teachers and bring such an amazing background to the course, it is truly an amazing opportunity to learn under them. Highlights from the course include working with physical objects from the collection every class, the guest speakers from the museum, the trips to west campus and NYC, and the final itself.
I would! I think this course is essential to everyone interested in art history!
